Eliminating Hamas was possible back in 2014 if it wasn't for the ceasefire that kept Hamas in power. 

The region can't afford another future war in Gaza. Hamas must be removed from power to achieve… https://t.co/YIvhSi2g3P

Pro Ceasefire advocates have been part of the problem, not the solution. 

Eliminating Hamas was possible back in 2014 if it wasn't for the ceasefire that kept Hamas in power. 

The region can't afford another future war in Gaza. Hamas must be removed from power to achieve long-lasting peace in the region. 

Defeating Hamas will end an era of Islamic violence. The defeat of Islamism for good.  

And those who have been under Hamas attack have the right to decide a ceasefire, not those who are sitting in comfort thousands of miles away.

data.text:
The consistency with which people who celebrated the launch of this war via atrocities on 10/7 are now claiming victim status due to the inevitable consequences of fighting such a war is really something.

There is a sense of entitlement. I get that they want to be able to murder… https://t.co/aRFpaN8cmu

note_tweet.text:
The consistency with which people who celebrated the launch of this war via atrocities on 10/7 are now claiming victim status due to the inevitable consequences of fighting such a war is really something.

There is a sense of entitlement. I get that they want to be able to murder innocent Jews without the Jews fighting back, but that’s not how the world works anymore. Wars are very costly, even for the “winners”. They are sometimes necessary, but that’s why you don’t launch them without understanding the consequences. 

Keep that in mind when you see people even now cheering on “the resistance” and Israel’s destruction while simultaneously acting outraged over the victims of the war they supported. All they are doing is volunteering more people to die. And no, calling for a ceasefire so Hamas can re-arm and launch another attack isn’t the same as supporting peace.

It's not like Hamas… https://t.co/gPAO8KSA4q

note_tweet.text:
Every once in a while I'll see a well-meaning liberal type on X write something like, "yeah I think Israel's military action is excessive, too much civilian death and destruction, but I'm kinda puzzled why people on the left don't call for Hamas to surrender. It's not like Hamas isn't an evil reactionary organization, peace isn't really possible with them in charge, and there would then be no excuse for Israel to continue to level Gaza."

I have an answer: Any real concern the relevant "people on the left" have about Gaza's civilians, about the prospects for peace, or about Hamas reign of terror are subsumed by their number 1 priority, which is that Israel lose. Hamas surrendering means Israel wins. A cease-fire with Hamas still in power means Israel loses. That's all that ultimately counts, which is why they demand a cease-fire, but never with the condition that Hamas be disarmed and removed from power.

data.text:
There are 13,000 UNRWA staff in Gaza.

That’s one UN staff for every 114 refugees in Gaza. Compare that to the largest refugee camp in the world, Cox Bazar with only 1,550 UN staff serving 1.24 million refugees. That’s one UN staff for every 800 refugees. In comparison, there are… https://t.co/2oR1lYQEg0

note_tweet.text:
There are 13,000 UNRWA staff in Gaza.

That’s one UN staff for every 114 refugees in Gaza. Compare that to the largest refugee camp in the world, Cox Bazar with only 1,550 UN staff serving 1.24 million refugees. That’s one UN staff for every 800 refugees. In comparison, there are 7 times more UN staff serving refugees in the Gaza Strip.

There are more UN staff in the Gaza Strip than the total employees of the World Bank with more than 10,000 employees in over 120 offices worldwide?

There are more UN staff in Gaza than in Geneva (8,500 UN staff) or New York (6,400 UN staff)? Gaza has twice as many UN Staff than in New York.

UNRWA leverages the UN brand to appear to casual observers as a team of relatively unbiased international aid workers, when in fact they're a $ 1 billion/year Palestinian business, run by Palestinians and staffed by Palestinians.

They need Palestinian refugees to exist. If Palestinians got their state, there would be no more "refugees," and the business and flow of aid money would end. It's in their best interests to perpetuate the conflict and leave Palestinian statehood up in the air. UNRWA schools literally taught a whole generation of Gazans to hate their neighbors and make unrealistic demands so that the core issue of sovereignty is never addressed.

Its sole achievements are radicalizing Palestinian children and keeping Palestinians refugees for generations. As you have read in the news recently, they also kept some of the hostages.

UNRWA should have been disbanded decades ago, all they do is perpetuate the conflict and keep Palestinians poor and uneducated.

data.text:
Oct 7 ONLY happened as a result of false promises, foolish leadership, a belief in utopian fantasies, and international pressure.

Arafat - Oslo - the PA - the disengagement - 
the path to Oct 7 took almost thirty years and the price Israelis have had to pay for the illusion of… https://t.co/yBrGjn6Wdp

note_tweet.text:
Oct 7 ONLY happened as a result of false promises, foolish leadership, a belief in utopian fantasies, and international pressure.

Arafat - Oslo - the PA - the disengagement - 
the path to Oct 7 took almost thirty years and the price Israelis have had to pay for the illusion of peace has been catastrophic.

It is not just the Oct 7 atrocity. Nor just the fallen soldiers. In the last few weeks 1000s of soldiers have had life changing injuries. The societal cost is beyond calculation.

So there is no turning back the clock to Oct 6. The Israelis will not - and should not ever accept such an outcome.

We have had enough of sacrificing Jews as part of some stupid attempt to be liked or accepted. Enough of choosing to accomodate daily threats against our existence. If anyone wants peace with Israel - then let them have it - but there will be no more games played with those that don't. No more weeping mothers paying a price for the empty dreams of naive fools.

The Jews suffered the worst atrocitiy since the Holocaust on Oct 7. Did it make any difference? Look around you at the hate - even in an hour of enormous grief - the streets of the west are full of people who choose to stand with the terrorists. 

The terrorists attempted a genocide of Jews and in our streets they sing for victory to the Intifada.

Media outlets have chosen to demonise Israel - simply for defending itself against terrorists. Celebrities - who said nothing as millions died elsewhere - suddenly obsess over Israel and share the words of Hamas spokesmen.

This is the reality of the world in which the Jews live. Since 1993 Israel tried over and over again to make peace. In return all it received were rockets - with the UN rushing to invoke article 99 as soon as Israel responded to the unspeakable atrocities of a death cult.

1993 and all that has happened since has been an awful mistake.  1000s of Jews have been buried for nothing.

The Israeli right wing told us the rockets would fly from Gaza as far back as 1994. They were ridiculed and called extremists. Turns out they were right all along. 

There is no current partner for peace. The Palestinians have no leader that can deliver on any promises. That is the truth we have to learn to accept. And not a single further Jewish life should be sacrified on the alter of fake promises. If one day they want peace - then let them come to us.

You think the world will hate us if we draw these lines in the sand? Look around you, they hate us anyway.

While I support Israel and its continued existence, I do think it's also important to recognize the things that weren't quite so "kosher" in its history.  For example a number of people brought up Deir Yassin.  Some of the approx 107 villagers murdered in the attack were merely… https://t.co/dPbIn4hPKr

note_tweet.text:
While I support Israel and its continued existence, I do think it's also important to recognize the things that weren't quite so "kosher" in its history.  For example a number of people brought up Deir Yassin.  Some of the approx 107 villagers murdered in the attack were merely fleeing or surrendering.  This was executed by Irgun and Lehi, which I think would be fair to characterize as violent extremist groups, or even terror groups.

The massacre was condemned by the leadership of the Haganah, and the Jewish Agency for Palestine sent Jordan's King Abdullah a letter of apology.

However, he held them responsible for it and warned of "terrible consequences" if similar incidents occurred.

Four days later, on April 13, there was a reprisal attack on the Hadassah medical convoy in Jerusalem which ended in a massacre killing 78 Jews, most of whom were the medical staff.  

I think it's fair to say that both sides had engaged in a fair bit of violence and brutality, before even the creation of Israel. There's been so many massacres on the Jewish populations for years and years prior to Israel. And I imagine that some of the Jews that came over to Palestine were thugs and willing to engage in similar tactics.

There were also the attacks on the British.

Some of the Arabs who fled Israeli territory I'm sure were simply afraid of reprisals by some of the more extremist elements. 

I think we need to acknowledge the pain of both people and realities if we are to move on.

But I also think we must live in the today and figure out solutions that might work for BOTH people TODAY.

No, it's not.

note_tweet.text:
The anger that Arab and Muslim Americans (and their allies) feel toward the Biden administration is so substantial that it’s hard to put into words.

And I keep seeing people discount it by saying it’s a few fringe groups.

No, it's not.

And those responding with “so they’re going to go for the Muslim ban guy,” are just wasting their time and making people even angrier.

Weird dynamic. On anti-Israel X feed, author says something absurd, such as "Israel has killed 20,000 children." You point out that this is wildly false, with citations. The author doesn't dispute the accuracy of your response, but instead says "you are an apologist for… https://t.co/NdR2wVGBdQ

note_tweet.text: Weird dynamic. On anti-Israel X feed, author says something absurd, such as "Israel has killed 20,000 children." You point out that this is wildly false, with citations. The author doesn't dispute the accuracy of your response, but instead says "you are an apologist for [something really awful]," and commenters chime in to say the same thing. This happens over and over. Truth is irrelevant, lies are fine so long as they serve to demonize Israel, people aren't the least bit embarrassed to be caught fabricating...
